awd_titl_txt: A robotic telescope for rapid astronomical observations and demonstration of hybrid adaptive optics
awd_abstract_narration:
Adaptive optics is a method of correcting telescope images for distortion caused by the Earth's atmosphere.  This technology enables ground-based astronomical telescopes to achieve resolutions otherwise obtainable only from space.  In this project, Baranec and collaborators build upon their highly successful precursor, Robo-AO, to deploy a second robotic adaptive optics system.  Innovations and upgrades will enable this new system to detect tens of thousands of astronomical objects per year and respond within minutes to unexpected discoveries.  It will be deployed at the University of Hawaii 2.2. m telescope on Mauna Kea, one the world's best observing sites.  It will inform development of adaptive optics on larger astronomical telescopes and provide training for students including underrepresented groups.

This current instrument will have several notable improvements over the previous design.  It will use a Selex Avalanche Photodiode Infrared Array (SAPHIRA) IR detector, whose development for adaptive optics is being independently supported by NSF.  Other upgrades will include a deformable mirror with more actuators (MEMS device from Boston Micromachines), and a UV laser guide star system.  The UV laser simplifies scheduling observations because it is not a safety threat to aircraft.  This project will demonstrate the hybrid-AO technique in which wavefront sensing of the laser guide star is used to improve the faintness limits obtainable with simultaneous sensing of natural guide stars.  This innovation greatly increases the on-sky availability of suitable targets for adaptive optics astronomical observations.

por.por_cntn:
Adaptive optics is a method of correcting telescope images that are otherwise distorted by the Earth's atmosphere. This technology enables ground-based astronomical telescopes to achieve resolutions otherwise obtainable only from space. In this project, Baranec and collaborators built upon their highly successful precursor prototype instrument, Robo-AO, to engineer and deploy a second robotic adaptive optics system, Robo-AO-2. Innovations and upgrades enable this new system to capture sharper images (approaching the resolution of the Hubble Space Telescope) of hundreds of astronomical objects per night, and to respond within minutes to unexpected discoveries. It is deployed at the University of Hawaii 2.2. m telescope on Maunakea, one the world's best observing sites, and will be made available to students, postdocs and other researchers within the University of Hawaii system as well to the U.S. and international astronomical community through six months of guaranteed observing time to foster survey-driven collaborations. Robo-AO-2 also includes auxiliary adaptive optics hardware that will be used to inform development of adaptive optics on larger astronomical telescopes.

Robo-AO-2 has several notable improvements over the previous design. It uses a Selex Avalanche Photodiode Infrared Array (SAPHIRA) IR detector, whose development for adaptive optics is being independently supported by NSF. It includes a deformable mirror with more actuators (MEMS device from Boston Micromachines); a faster and lower-noise laser wavefront sensor camera; a reconfigurable stellar wavefront sensor camera, an internal telescope simulator with an astrometric reference source, and a higher-power UV laser guide star system. The UV laser simplifies scheduling observations because it is not a safety threat to aircraft. This project will demonstrate hybrid-AO techniques in which wavefront sensing of the laser guide star is used to improve the faintness limits obtainable with simultaneous sensing of natural guide stars. This innovation greatly increases the on-sky availability of suitable targets for adaptive optics astronomical observations.

Over the course of this award, students worked alongside senior project personnel on many aspects of the hardware and software of the Robo-AO-2 instrument. This includes 3 graduate students, 8 undergraduates (through part-time paid research, the NSF funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates, and the Akamai Workforce Initiative), and 2 high-school students. The project provided students with experience with modern telescope instrumentation and techniques, training critical to nearly all major astronomical instrument initiatives planned for the coming decade.
